climbs.name: Viscous Variation
climbs.fa: Tim Laughlin, Todd Burrill, Rich James

content.description:
A definite R belongs to this one. Looks pretty mellow from the ground, but the low angle can fool you. Gear is shallow, thin, few and far between. Think of it as a badly protected easy highball problem. Only it's not easy!

Easily toproped by leading most of the first pitch of the Regular Route and clipping the chains you pass. Helps for toprope to have some long slings to extend rope over the edge.
content.protection: Gear to 1", nuts, offset nuts, and tricams helpful. Good anchors at the top.
content.location: 15' to the left of the Regular Route, just look up and see if you can see somewhere, anywhere for pro.

content.description: Another one of those "gear is poor and infrequent" R lines. FA climbed 13's. There is no gear for the first 3rd of the climb, then bad pro to the top.
content.protection: Gear to 1" nuts, tri-cams, offset nuts help. Good anchors at top
content.location: Left of Viscous Variation, look for the steeper blank face start.

content.description: 5' right of Mojito, the rock angle eases, the gear gets better, and climbing easier. Follow the natural weakness up onto the ledge and move either left or right to anchors
content.protection: Standard rack to 3", nut work well.
content.location: A more obvious line with visible gear placements. Look for a small right tending arch. Rap from either the top of Viscous Variation or Mojito.

content.description:
Tim Loughlin was a prolific route setter in the early days of the development of Lassen Park. This is one of his last, and one of his best, lines.

The line follows the left side of the awesome arete which dominates the crag. It's hard to forget you are at 9,500'.
content.protection: 14 bolts. Bolted anchor. 2 ropes needed for rappel.
content.location:
The best way to approach the route is to climb Clas von Bulow. You can also use the Regular Route, or Tres Hombres.

The line of 13 bolts to the right is 'The Red Knight', the line of 14 bolts on the left is 'The Trophy'.

content.description: The farthest right (downhill) of the Trinity Cracks. A thin line which slowly widens to (large) fist. Climbed infrequently, can be dirty. And yes, there are more than three in this trinity, go figure.
content.protection: Standard gear to 3+". Doubles .5-3. Can be broken into 2 pitches if needed. Gear anchor. Walk off climbers left, lousy scree/talus.
content.location: Well above Tangerine Dream, just below where the 3rd class walk off for the western climbs on the belly, there is a steep wall broken with a number of cracks. This is the farthest downhill, the first you find on the approach. There are no bolted anchors, can be tough to build anchor on top if you top out before bringing up follower.

content.description: This is the one you came for. The center of the '3' Trinity cracks climbs great jams all the way to the top.
content.protection: Double rack to 3". Emphasis on fingers-hands. This thing loves nuts!
content.location: To the right, uphill side of the small roof, there is a triangular alcove. The crack slits this alcove and heads pretty much straight up.

content.description: The farthest down hill of the '3' Trinity cracks. Not counting the 'Trinity Crack Far Right' fourth crack (?). This one almost rates a PG-13 for the technicality of the pro above the roof. Tough for the grade, and you are at 9,500'+. Almost classic.
content.protection: Double rack to 3". Offset nuts, tricams, etc.
content.location: Locate a small roof down low. A thin crack ascends the center-right of this, then turns into a long, technical, line.

content.description: This line would rate 3 stars if it went all the way to the top. As it is, it finishes on an easy (4th?) ramp. The upper most of the Trinity Cracks.The easiest of the 3 (4) Trinity Cracks.
content.protection: Double to 3".
content.location: Above left of the roof and alcove, starts in an inset above a scree pile. Belayer should watch for falling junk!

climbs.name: Tres Hombres
climbs.fa: Mark Mates, Travis Klawin, John Bald

content.description:
The wide one. Locate the orange pillar of 'The Trophy'. Tres Hombres starts directly below this. Be comfortable with OW, this one is sustained.

Pitch 1) Follow the crack to a shallow sloping ledge. Belay in the crack in the corner.

Pitch 2) The crack continues up and to the right. Belay at the point where the crack widens to OW.

Pitch 3) The money. Belay where the crack thins and becomes more of a dihedral.

Pitch 4) A short steep section eases off to the top.
content.protection: Double rack to 6". All natural anchors.
content.location: Locate the orange pillar of 'The Trophy'. Tres Hombres starts directly below this.

content.description:
Might be the best moderate on the Belly. Great pro, perfect cracks from fingers to off-fist and big exposure make this a classic line.

P1) 65' Look for a large detached blocky flake sitting 15' from the ground on a sloping ledge. Climb the left facing corner passing above the flake, to a right traverse under a knobby bulge, up a short crack to a very large comfortable ledge where you will find anchors on the far left.

P2) 60' Wonderful pitch gets right to it. Leave the ledge on the far left which starts out thin hands and quickly gets off fist. Gear anchor.

P3) A short thin finger crack leads up and to the right to the bolted belay on a huge ledge.

P4) The Dream pitch. Go straight up the deceivingly steep hand to off fist crack to bolted anchors. Awesome!
content.protection: Double rack .3 to 3", 1-4". Offset nuts work well. Slings a must.
content.location: Stand back and look for the detached block/flake. Starts left and passes the block. A 70m rope just makes the rap from P3 to P1.

content.description:
The first pitch of this deserves 4 stars, the second and third 2, hence the overall 3 star rating. Double ropes needed to rap. Otherwise top out as for Tres Hombres and walk off exposed 3rd class to climbers left.

Pitch 1) A short traverse with thin pro leads to a left facing corner to the right of the arete. The crack widens and narrows, leading to a ledge with anchors on the far left (shared with 4 other routes). This pitch is 180+'.

Pitch 2) It's best to have scoped this from the ground; move up and right through a series of ledges to the base of a steep dihedral. Short pitch.

Pitch 3) Finish as for Tres Hombres, up a short steep section, then topping out and walking off to the climbers left.
content.protection: Double (at least) very thin to 5". The first pitch is long and may require backcleaning for mere mortals. Micros/ballnuts in the start.
content.location: Look for a small ledge which leads right to a small left facing corner. As with many of the climbs here, standing back helps.

climbs.name: Remote Luxery
climbs.fa: Pitch 1:John Bald, Greg Laurie   Pitch 2: Dave Caunt, Stan Miller, Rob Settlemire

content.description:
This climb starts at the first belay of Tangerine Dream.

P1)From the large ledge after climbing P1 of Tangerine Dream, exit the ledge on the far right up a steep hand-crack to a comfy edge. There is loose rock reported on this pitch.

P2)From the ledge follow a line of 7 bolts to the top of the crag and the bolted anchor.

The second belay (the top of P1 of Luxery) is shared by 4 routes. It is possible to rap from here w/2 60m ropes.
content.protection: Double rack to 3". 7 bolts. Bolted anchor.
content.location: From the large ledge on the top of P1 of Tangerine Dream. Rap w/2 60m ropes or walk off to climbers left.

climbs.name: The Regular Route
climbs.fa: John Yates, Steve Lauderdale, Travis Klawin

content.description:
A 3 (or 4) pitch route more popular for it's ease of 'getting to the top' than for it's pure aesthetics, fun, with lots of variations and possibilities. Originally believed to be the first line on the Belly (1984); Tangerine Dream' squeezed it out by 4 years (1980)

Pitch 1: Starts just left of the toe, up an easy (5.6R) steep knobby face with little pro. 65' to the left traverse onto 'First Terrace'. Walk to the back corner of the terrace, bolted belay. 90'

Pitch 2: Climb the corner above the belay. The original line (5.8) is the leftmost crack in the corner,, there are easier variation just to the right of this. Ends on the 'Second Terrace'. 90'

Pitch 3: Head into the left corner, up a small ledge/ramp. There are many choices of cracks to choose from, the original Regular Route used the left hand crack to start, then switched into the OW/chimney to finish at the bolted belay.

Descent for 3rd Pitch: Recommended. Rap from belay to top of Second Terrace. Downclimb on belay to anchors above "Clast Von Bulow". Difficult to find if not familiar with the route.

Optional 4th pitch: NOT RECOMMENDED: Continue up through the choss, loose rock and ledges (easy 5th) to the top. From the top of the 4th pitch the descent is a short rap (you will need slings or to leave gear behind) into the scree behind the crag to the northwest. Walk/slide down dirty, loose, lousy scree to the base. Not worth it.
content.protection: Standard rack to 5" depending on the variation. Doubles in fingers and hands for some. Tricams work well on pockets throughout the park. Here as well.
content.location: The climb starts just to the left of the lowest point of the crag, the toe. UP and to the left approximately 65' is the 'First Terrace'.

content.description: SEE REGULAR ROUTE FOR DESCRIPTION AND FIRST 2 PITCHES: In the corner start of the 3rd pitch, climb the left hand most crack in the corner. Stellar hands/fingers.
content.protection: Same as Regular Route, doubles .5-1". Offset nuts.
content.location: See Regular Route.

content.description: Two bolted lines dominate the arete looming over the First Terrace. This is the right hand route. Steep pocketed with fine edges, this is only slightly easier than 'The Trophy'. A beautiful line, with great exposure.
content.protection: 13 bolts, bolted anchor. 2 ropes to rappel.
content.location: The right most bolted line overhanging the First Terrace. Best approached by climbing Clas von Bulow, alternately use the Regular Route or Tres Hombres.

content.description:
Is it there? Does it go to the top? Only The Great Unknown (FA) knows for sure.

A purported 4th class/easy 5th ramp ascends diagonally from the same start as Hades.
content.protection: Rack to 3"
content.location: Follow the ramp up and right from the start of Hades.

content.description: This is the first line going up the hill to the left of Regular Route which does not end on the First Terrace. Follow 3 bolts up to a ledge, then leave the ledge on 1 more bolt before hitting an 'easier' crack, ending up traversing to the chains above 'Clast von Bulow'. The second bolt has ground fall potential.
content.protection: 4 bolts, standard rack to 2".
content.location: This is the first line going up the hill to the left of Regular Route which does not end on the First Terrace. Look for 3 bolts which lead to a ledge, above which is a 4th bolt. Easier to see if you stand back from the wall.

content.description: A fun, sparsely protected line, which ascends a good pockets and edges. Find a single bolt in a shallow groove, then pull the crux to the ledge above.
content.protection: Small gear and one bolt. Tricams work well in the pockets.
content.location: Standing back from the toe below first terrace, look to the left and find where the wall has a deep undercut triangle shape. There are 2 shiny bolts which you can see. This is not the climb! Mejito starts 5' to the right of this.

content.description:
Towards the top of the west face of the belly, above The Trinity Cracks, are 2 or 3 more lines. Hades starts in the same location as the Ramp, only follow the crack up and trend left. At the top follow the crack slightly right to a decent gear belay. Walk off to climbers left.

This thing can be hard to figure out, wanders some. Breaking it into 2 short pitches keeps the rope drag down.
content.protection: Double rack to 3", #4.
content.location: Locate the easy ramp which cuts across the top of Trinity cracks. Start here, but move up and left. Walk off climbers left through crappy talus/scree field.

content.description: Just uphill from Pyroclastic is this steep somewhat confusing (up close) route. Stand back and it makes more sense. Starts on 2 bolts over steep rock, tending right and up to a small ledge, into a shallow corner and onto a second ledge from which you follow the easier face above passing 2 more bolts.
content.protection: 4 bolts, small rack (think small) to 1". Bolted anchor.
content.location: As you approach the crag, look up at the awesome arete looming above the left side of the First Terrace. The arete is the 4 star 5.12.a route "The Trophy", which is directly above Clast von Bulow. The anchor for Clast is the start of the Trophy.

content.description: Steep pockets and knobs flow up into a water streaked face. Gear is sparse, but good protection through the meat of the climb. It is best to bring up the second and rap from the anchor in the back of first terrace as there are no anchors directly on top of the line.
content.protection: 2 bolts, small gear. Tricams for the pockets.
content.location: Just to the left of Mojito, find 2 bolts leading through a water streaked face. Best to rap from the Regular Route chains, lots of friction over the first terrace ledge.

content.description: The uppermost route on the west face of the Belly. Broken cracks wander up towards the top of the uppermost 'pinnacle'. The route tops out to the right of the high point.
content.protection: Standard rack (doubles?) to 3". Tricams and offset nuts are a plus.
content.location: Stand back and locate the upper point (pinnacle). Find the start below and to the left of this. The crack is not continuous, be creative!

content.description:
Sandbagged 5.9+. Be a comfortable 10+ climber to swing this one!

Just below Tangerine Dream is a shallow, short, left facing corner. Ascend this to another left facing corner. This transitions into a bold 5.8 face protected by 2 (two) bolts. PG-13! (R). Pro is scarce, so when you find it, plug it! Head towards the left facing corner/dihedral which ends on a large ledge shared by 4 other routes.
content.protection: Double (+) rack to 2". Tricams for the pockets. Slings for knobs. Double 60m just reaches the ground for descent.
content.location: Find Tangerine Dream. Just to the left, downhill, there are 3 bolts on a steep face. Attitude starts in the left corner between.

content.description: A heady, steep (for the grade) climb, sustained for the first half. Tough finding pro, but it's there.
content.protection: Small gear to 1". Offsets rock. Tricams in pockets.
content.location:
The farthest left line which goes to the First Terrace. You have two options for the top.

1) As you top out on first terrace follow the ledge to the back corner, rap from the first anchor of Regular Route.

2) Continue up the arete to Second Terrace (5.10.a).
